The Logrus Denizens Household Community archive

Godskids

Godskids

02-06-1997

godskids


Are Children Welcome at Worship?
A summary of children's worship practices in Anglican, Lutheran and other churches in Calgary, Alberta Canada.

Background:
I contacted, visited, or met with parishioners from, each of the churches on the following list. The contacts took place, for the most part, in 1997/1998. I was looking for a church home for my family, but as the list was compiled, I decided to publish it on the Internet for three reasons:
    1. At that time, there was no central Internet listing where one could find the service times and contact information for every Anglican church in Calgary. Many churches simply didn't see the Internet as a relevant resource. I saw it as an obvious (and essentially cost-free) means of reaching out. Thus, I included that information for anyone who hit this page with that concern as their search criteria. A more authoritative resource which has since been established is http://www.calgary.anglican.ca/Parishes/parish-index.html. (which you may wish to visit instead of this if that's what you're really looking for)
    2. In my visits or meetings I sought out other mothers of young children in order to get first-hand opinions from the people most affected by attitudes toward children. Many of them told me they were engaged in a similar search for a church home that truly met their needs. But, since such a search is punishingly difficult for those who are already struggling to raise spiritually health children while lacking spiritual nurture themselves, many were settling for unsatisfactory situations on the margin of acceptance in their existing congregations. I wanted to let them and other mothers like them, know what I was finding out. If indeed they were settling for the best that was practically available to them, this research could help them accept that situation. If there was a better situation for them, this research might help them find it.
    3. In some respects, the Internet looks a lot like the chapel door of Wittenberg Castle. Just as in the sixteenth century a subject for public discussion would routinely be posted on the church door, in the twenty-first century a subject is posted on the internet.  Although the notion of intergenerational worship and mutual acceptance including children is not new, and the unhappy mothers I was talking to were not invisible, churches simply weren't engaging the issue. After I posted these pages (and they were linked for a week by Anglicans Online) I received email from people around the world, encouraging me or challenging me, letting me know of different ways that individual churches do embrace children or of programmes and consulting services available to churches to improve their inclusivity. I've received advice from Anglican priests from New Zealand to Massachussets to the Arctic; I've heard from people who have added my essays to their Children's Ministry resources and who have implemented ideas that I've proposed here. I've also heard from two Calgary priests who wanted to challenge what I'd said about their churches -- but who hadn't read any of the website. From those discussions I know that the issues did enter into word-of-mouth discussions within the diocese, too. I suspect the result of those discussions shows in those local parish websites that now describe themselves as child-friendly on their home-pages. The question remains as to what has changed beyond their websites. Since a main point of posting these listings was to generate discussion, I've put my email address in a number of places. Please use it if you want to discuss with me! (mailto: pamela@logrus.ca)
Six years have passed since I compiled this listing. Where I have since revisited or discussed the church with parishioners I have updated the information. However, in those intervening six years there has been some discussion of children's inclusion. I've added a number of parish websites to the list below, and if you review them you may note that many sites explicitely state that they are child-welcoming and that Nursery/Sunday School are optional. If you are a mother of preschoolers who has direct experience to ground any of those statements, please  email me, as your observations are what make those statements credible. You don't have to be a member, agree with me or like the church, just be frank about what's happening. The people who use this list are smart enough to draw their own conclusions.

There is nothing official about this list. The comments and ratings indicate my own impressions and those of my correspondents only. All opinions expressed are completely subjective. If they're indicative of any group, it's working mothers of the post-Boom and pre-"generation X" culture.

Where did this come from?


Advent Evangelical Lutheran 
Church in Canada,  of Calgary, Alberta, Canada

239-6966 

11 Scenic Acres Gate
http://www.adventlutheran.ca/

13

Nursury:

    available 

Sunday School

    between services 

Pastor lectured on the subject of "Welcoming Children to Worship" at the 2000 ELCIC worship conference in Cqamrose, from a well-informed and childe-affirming perspective. Congregation has an elaborate children's ministery incorporating "faith chests" for newly baptized children, which are then filled with mementos of their faith journey.

Last updated 2000 - August

Children are welcome at:

    Gathering of the Community? yes

    Ministry of the Word? yes

    Prayers of the People? yes 

    The Lord's Supper? yes

    Dismissal: yes

*

Faith 

10:30 Blended Traditional/Contemporary Worship

*
Last updated 2000 - Fall

13

Nursury:

    available 

Sunday School

    before service (9:30)

Information contained herein derives from several visits; and from the experience of a long-time member
Cloth books and crayons provided in Narthex. When the visiting mother removed her crying toddler, one parishioner followed her out to help. Elder children befriended the visiting pre-schooler and showed her how to behave. 
Parishioners marked prayer-book for visitors. Communion is by grape juice, wine in individual cup, or wine from common cup - your choice. 

Children are welcome from birth, even when they act like children. Many members, especially older ones, make a point of encouraging parents to bring their children regularly. Church leaders make it clear that parents and children are welcome to come to the
front.  Music is chosen with children's participation in mind. At special occasions children lead the processions and bring in special offerings.
The service includes a children's story, while striving that the whole
service should engage children.

Children are welcome at:

    Gathering of the Community? yes

    Ministry of the Word? yes

    Prayers of the People? yes

    The Lord's Supper? yes

    Dismissal? yes

*

Emmanuel Evangelical Lutheran 
Church of Calgary, Alberta, Canada

    9:15
    10:30 

272-1551 
3403 19 Av SE
*
Last updated 1999 - Jan
http://www3.telus.net/public/emmanue1/

12

Nursury:

    parents room 

Sunday School 

    10:30 Service

Information contained herein derives from regular attendance

 When we started attending, a large mural on the outside proclaims "Let the Children Come" -- since then that church building has been sold and Emmanuel is worshipping with Saint Luke's Anglican church. Children are given the elements if they are already communicants, otherwise the Pastor encourages waiting. Liturgical nature of the service is downplayed compared to other ELCIC churches. 

Children are welcome at:

    Gathering of the Community? yes

    Ministry of the Word? yes

    Prayers of the People? yes 

    The Lord's Supper? partial

    Dismissal: yes

Sharon Evangelical Lutheran 
Church in Canada,  of Calgary, Alberta, Canada

10:00 - Sunday School
11:00 - Family Worship

277-4085
210 10 Ave NE 
*
Last updated 1998-09-27

6

Nursury:

    crying room 

Sunday School

    before service 

Information contained herein derives from attendance at several services, one phone conversation with the pastor, and conversations with a long-time (now lapsed) member.
*
Caution: although in theory Sharon scores a perfect 14, in practice on many Sundays *no* children were observed at the family service, which is primarily attended by senior citizens. 
The actual presence of children is the only valid evidence of their sincere welcome. 
Caution: although a brochure in the pew states that all Baptised persons are welcome to receive the Eucharist and that families are encouraged to communicate together, when the children did come up for communion they were firmly denied the elements. 

Children are welcome at:

    Gathering of the Community? in theory

    Ministry of the Word? in theory

    Prayers of the People? in theory 

    The Lord's Supper? BANNED

    Dismissal? in theory

St Stephen's Anglican 
Church of Calgary, Alberta, Canada

8:00 BCP Eucharist

10:30 BAS Eucharist 

244-4879
1121 14 Av SW 
*
Last updated 2003 - Fall
http://www.ststephenscalgary.org/


6

Nursury:

    available 

Sunday School

    during service

Information contained herein is the opinion of a 15-year member, and from the website.
Intolerant acts during the '97 Easter services brought into question Saint Stephen's welcome to children. Church leaders responded by dividing the congregation into "Traditional" and "Contemporary"; hiring musical leadership for the latter, and hiring a non-volunteer Sunday School teacher.
Since that time Saint Stephen's has had a change of rector, and recombined the separated services.

Children are welcome at:

    Gathering of the Community? yes

    Ministry of the Word? no

    Prayers of the People? no

    The Lord's Supper?yes

    Dismissal? yes

*

St Martin's Anglican 
Church of Calgary, Alberta, Canada
8:30
10:00 BAS 

249-3014 
2210 28 St SW 
*
Data last checked 1997 - Summer
http://www.stmartinscalgary.ca/

6

Nursury:

    not optional

Sunday School

    not optional

    curriculum:

    Living the God News

Information contained herein derives from one visit, the frank opinions of a long-time member.
When I visited the church in 1997 there were ~ 20 children all of whom were sent out for Sunday School; the first words said to me were "you know we have a nursury, don't you?"; and one mother recounted receiving hints to remove her children, once three times in a single service.
Since that time Saint Martins has moved to a new site on the edge of the city, in a suburban area with younger families.

Children are welcome at:

    Gathering of the Community? yes

    Ministry of the Word? no

    Prayers of the People? no

    The Lord's Supper? yes

    Dismissal: yes

    new 

Information contained herein derives from one visit phone call with church office staff.
Secretary says children are welcome and some do stay in worship. This was not observed. One parishioner expressed horror that toddlers might ever receive communion. 

"Smells and Bells". Evensong 3rd Sundays, Prayer Book Society influence, does not use Common Lectionary Poor pointing or obscure setting, and sung gospel made mass hard to follow. Incense triggered asthma even at the back of the church. 

Children are welcome at:

    Gathering of the Community? no

    Ministry of the Word? no

    Prayers of the People? no

0

Nursury:

    not optional 

Sunday School

    not optional 

    curriculum: 

    Conservative Episcopal 

Information contained herein derives from one phone call with Father Guthrie.
Children's Liturgy once per month. Rector recounted an anecdote regarding expelling children at some other parish. Rector said that children if normally present tend to usurp the focus of worship. 

Children are welcome at:

    Gathering of the Community? expelled

    Ministry of the Word? expelled

    Prayers of the People? expelled

    The Lord's Supper? school-age

    Dismissal: yes

First Four-square Gospel Calgary, Alberta, Canada
10:00
F, Sa 7pm 

250-7754
1221 48 Ave NE 
*
Data last checked 1997 - Summer

?


Information contained herein derives from one visit.
Children take part at Gathering (praise music), then go out to Sunday school or stay with parents. Preaching is informal and accessible. Contemplation time is held after the end of the service. 
visit 

Sunday school taught by teens. Uses lively music, bible study (KJV is used with children reading to study partners) and crafts 

Host member had kept her toddler in for two years without feeling unwelcome. Movement by children is tolerated and there is space for spontaneous dancing at the back. Play space is provided for the children during contemplation.S


*

Grace Baptist 

4th Street and 13 Avenue SW 
*
Data last checked 1997 - Fall

?


Information contained herein derives from two visits.

Children are generally out of church in Sunday School, but are accepted if their parents chose to keep them in. 


*

Centre Street Evangelical 

4120 Centre Street North 
*
Data last checked 1997 - Fall

?


Information contained herein derives from the opinions of long-time members.
Children are generally out of church in Sunday School except on festival Sundays or when performing as members of the junior choir. Families who keep their children in sit together in the balconey. 
9:00 service is primarily adults-only.
